Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: The register beeped insistently as I counted the bills, my mind focused on the numbers. It was the end of my shift, and I knew any mistake now could mean hours of paperwork and a stern talk from my manager. My phone buzzed in my pocket. I glanced at the screen—my best friend’s name flashed, and I hesitated. I answered quietly, and immediately heard the tremble in their voice. “Can you talk? I really need you right now,” they said, barely holding back tears. My heart twisted. I wanted to drop everything, listen, and be the friend they needed, but a line was forming and the drawer was open, stacks of cash exposed. My manager’s expectation echoed in my mind: no distractions, no errors. I tried to split my attention, but the numbers blurred and my friend’s words faded into the background. I felt torn, guilt rising as I realized I couldn’t be fully present for either role. The pressure built inside me, and I stood there, caught between the demands of my job and the needs of my friend, unsure which responsibility to honor.
